oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery On The Record with Brooks and Dunn - Part 1
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Brooks and Dunn (performance group) for Ralph Emery: On the Record With Brooks and Dunn. Recording is performed in front of a live audience. Interview features a segment featuring Merle Haggard (performer). Recording is from May 02, 1995. Tape is labeled part 1.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Brooks and Dunn
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:35) Ralph Emery introduces Ronnie Dunn and Kix Brooks by listing their accolades -- (01:33) Emery inquires about where the idea for "Boot Scootin' Boogie," and Dunn attributes it to his time in Texas -- (03:34) Emery, Brooks, and Dunn discuss how "Boot Scootin' Boogie" was originally pitched to Asleep at the Wheel -- (04:17) Emery praises "Brand New Man;" additionally, Dunn reflects on the creative process behind "Brand New Man" -- (06:03) Emery inquires about the bet associated with "Brand New Man" -- (08:00) Brooks and Dunn discuss how they had first met at a lunch set up by Tim DuBois -- (11:01) Emery reads an interview stating that Brooks and Dunn were close to giving up -- (13:05) Emery inquires on how the personalities of Brooks and Dunn manifested during early shows -- (15:15) Emery inquires about how Brooks jumped off the stage at West Fest -- (16:37) Emery recalls a time where he skied with Reba McEntire wearing a Brooks and Dunn hat -- (19:00) Emery recants how Brooks and Dunn were unsure of the duration of their partnership -- (21:00) Emery plays a clip of DuBois talking about how Brooks and Dunn built their chemistry -- (21:50) Emery, Brooks, and Dunn joke about the intelligence of DuBois and 'Okies;' additionally, the chemistry behind Brooks and Dunn is questioned by Emery -- (25:16) Emery asks about the special concerts Brooks and Dunn performs -- (29:11) Emery questions where Brooks and Dunn came across the expressions behind "Little Miss Honky Tonk" -- (30:00) Emery inquires about the injuries Brooks had inquired whilst moving around on stage; additionally, Emery asks about the multilingual expressions of "Rock My World" -- (33:01) Emery asks about Brooks' childhood background -- (35:19) Emery presents a couple pictures of Brooks on a horse as a child, and asks Brooks why he was named Kix -- (39:02) Emery has Brooks discuss Leon Brooks and Brooks and Dunn's similar interest in the oil business -- (41:03) Emery inquires about how Dunn's father performed with Sonny James; additionally, Emery asks Dunn to reflect on his father's definition of country music -- (44:56) Emery readdresses why Dunn had received a girl's bicycle for Christmas -- (47:44) Emery inquires about Brooks and Dunn's colligate performance -- (53:46) Emery and Brooks discuss the clothing store Brooks worked at -- (55:48) Emery inquires about Brooks' immediate family -- (58:25) Brooks reflects on how Leon Brooks would not see Brooks for quite some time -- (1:01:46) Emery invites Brooks to discuss Merle Haggard and if he would like to meet Haggard -- (1:02:23) Emery introduces Haggard, and Haggard expresses how he enjoys Brooks and Dunn's efforts -- (1:04:40) Haggard recalls how he was intimidated when he met Lefty Frizzell -- (1:05:59) Haggard recalls a time Elvis Presley wished to meet Haggard and Bonnie Owens
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Emery, Ralph; Brooks & Dunn (Musical group); Haggard, Merle; Haggard, Merle, 1937-2016; Brooks, Kix; Dunn, Ronnie;
